Introduction: 4pr1 begins “Athamas, the king in Thessaly, married Themisto, the daughter of a nymph.” (*Athamas in Thessalia rex duxit nymphae filiam Themistonem uxorem*).  It continues > *Ex ea filio habuit*.

Section 9pr1 begins “Amphion and Zetus drove the son of the king into exile.” (*Amphion et Zetus Labdaci regis filium in exsilium eiecerunt.*)  It continues >**ipsi** *regnum obtinuerunt.*  (*obtinuerunt* = "They obtained").

Section 4pr5 begins, “Themisto killed her children.” (*Themisto filios occidit.*)  When she realizes what she has done, she commits suicide.  Vocabulary: *ubi*, "when"; *resciit*, "she recognized"; *necauit*, "she killed"; *se*, "herself (direct object)".  It continues >**id** *ubi resciit, **ipsa** se necauit.*

Section 15pr6 begins “The women of Lemnos conceived children from the Argonauts.” (*Lemniades filios ex Argonautis conceperunt.*)  Vocabulary: *imposuerunt* “They set or placed (direct object in accusative) upon (indirect object in dative). “ It continues > **eorum** *nomina filiis imposuerunt.*

Section 31pr9 begins, “Hercules killed Eurytus because…” (*Hercules Eurytum occidit, quod...*) Vocabulary:  *petiit*, “s/he sought, asked for”; *coniugium, coniugii* (n.) “marriage”; *repudiauit* “s/he rejected”.  The passage continues > *filiam **eius** in coniugium petiit et **ille** **eum** repudiauit*.
